description: The CCNA Security show will build knowledge of network infrastructure security, increase understanding core security concepts, show how to configure and manage secure access, VPN encryption, firewalls, intrusion prevention, web and email content security, and endpoint security using different security technologies.  Also demonstrates how install, troubleshoot, and monitor these technologies to achieve business defined security goals.

episodes.description: In this episode, Jo and Ronnie discuss the cia triad and siem technology.  They describe the components and purpose of the CIA triad and provide examples for each component.  Also they take the time to describe SIEM technology and talk about what it does and should perform: aggregation, correlation and retention.
episodes.title: Describe CIA Triad and SIEM Technology

authentication traffic only until

00:25:19.585 --> 00:25:23.783

00:25:54.530 --> 00:25:56.808

00:26:06.760 --> 00:26:10.894
Whereas, TACACS says you can actually

00:26:10.894 --> 00:26:13.957

00:26:13.957 --> 00:26:16.615
You can put a TACACS authorization server.

00:26:16.615 --> 00:26:21.971

00:26:21.971 --> 00:26:26.823

00:26:26.823 --> 00:26:32.094

00:26:32.094 --> 00:26:35.850
And then as information is sent,
it goes to another machine.

469
00:26:35.850 --> 00:26:37.519
This provides for us resiliency.

00:26:37.519 --> 00:26:38.987
I bring down one component,

00:26:38.987 --> 00:26:42.630
I don't necessarily bring down
the other components, okay?

00:26:42.630 --> 00:26:43.900
So you can do that if you choose to.

Yes, okay, all three of them

episodes.description: Description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe use of IPsec as a framework.  They discuss that IPsec is comprised of matching hashing algorithm, authentication, DH group #, limited availability,and encryption.  They describe what is involved with Phase 1 (SA) and Phase 2 (encryption).

when you here somebody say an IPSec

which is a virtual private network.

00:01:51.350 --> 00:01:55.145

if you haven't heard that term before,

well this may be a little bit more

39

41

actually had an office that expanded

But once stuff like
that started happening,

49
00:02:36.800 --> 00:02:38.407
And in the earliest days,

50
00:02:38.407 --> 00:02:42.950
the way to be able to do something like

51
00:02:42.950 --> 00:02:47.582
So what we would do is that we would just
establish a point-to-point connection

52
00:02:47.582 --> 00:02:51.748

53

that was there that was normally

55

61
00:03:26.370 --> 00:03:30.500

>> Well some of them could

>> Okay.

00:04:22.640 --> 00:04:25.440

you want to make sure, excuse me,

you just want to make sure that your
data never has to touch the Internet.

00:04:29.190 --> 00:04:31.530
So you can establish that

00:04:31.530 --> 00:04:34.080

overall though that can

00:04:40.720 --> 00:04:43.230
as they started having
these types of connections,

85
00:04:43.230 --> 00:04:46.560
realized that they were just going to

86
00:04:46.560 --> 00:04:49.510
So one of the big advantages that
they started taking advantage of,

87
00:04:49.510 --> 00:04:52.730
of course, is the idea of

88
00:04:52.730 --> 00:04:57.860
a virtual private network, that would
link these different sites together.

89
00:04:57.860 --> 00:05:01.950
But this time we would use the existing
infrastructure of the Internet, and

90
00:05:01.950 --> 00:05:05.680
instead of running a private
line outside of the Internet

91
00:05:05.680 --> 00:05:08.900
we would actually create a virtual tunnel.

92
00:05:08.900 --> 00:05:14.700
And that virtual tunnel would connect the

93
00:05:14.700 --> 00:05:18.310
But that tunnel that was connected across
the Internet not only provided a point to

94
00:05:18.310 --> 00:05:22.660
point link, but it could also

95
00:05:22.660 --> 00:05:26.640
And today we are gonna be talking

96
00:05:26.640 --> 00:05:29.290
which is one of the protocol

00:05:29.290 --> 00:05:31.500
there's a few other ones

00:05:31.500 --> 00:05:35.090
But we're specifically of course

99
00:05:35.090 --> 00:05:40.250
We're also gonna talk about IKE, which is

100
00:05:40.250 --> 00:05:44.980
And I wanna break it down for us so that
we understand how these protocols work.

101
00:05:44.980 --> 00:05:49.770
I can just tell you, okay, when you create

00:05:49.770 --> 00:05:54.540
IPSec or you're gonna use IKE or you're

103
00:05:54.540 --> 00:05:57.200
I can just tell you that, and
that's just the way it's gonna be, okay.

104
00:05:57.200 --> 00:06:02.110
It doesn't make sense a lot of times on
why we'd choose to use one over the other

105
00:06:02.110 --> 00:06:04.090
or how they actually work.

106
00:06:04.090 --> 00:06:07.980
So we're gonna talk about each of these
different protocols a little bit so

107
00:06:07.980 --> 00:06:11.260
that we have an understanding that I'm
breaking it down to the header level so

108
00:06:11.260 --> 00:06:15.160
that you can see what happens
when we start to do this, okay.

109
00:06:15.160 --> 00:06:20.415
So in the concerns when start talking
about the idea of IPSec protocols, okay.

110
00:06:20.415 --> 00:06:23.770
Where does IPSec come from and
what is this about?

111
00:06:23.770 --> 00:06:27.406
Well let's kinda break this down

112
00:06:27.406 --> 00:06:30.899
IP is normally written in capital

113
00:06:30.899 --> 00:06:33.810
which is what it's short for

114
00:06:33.810 --> 00:06:37.990
The security side, or sec,

115
00:06:37.990 --> 00:06:41.838
You hear people say ipsec,
that's the one that always gets me, but

116
00:06:41.838 --> 00:06:44.050
you'll hear people say
it all the time,okay.

117
00:06:44.050 --> 00:06:45.710
ipsec, I say IPSec.

118
00:06:45.710 --> 00:06:47.840
Everybody will probably say something.

119
00:06:47.840 --> 00:06:50.860
One or the other, those are usually
the two most common ways to do this.

120
00:06:50.860 --> 00:06:54.650
>> So Ronnie, what is it that we need
to know about the IPSec protocols?

121
00:06:54.650 --> 00:06:57.760
>> Well when it comes down to
IPSec itself and the protocol,

122
00:06:57.760 --> 00:07:02.710
what we need to know is that the protocol
itself is really designed because

123
00:07:02.710 --> 00:07:06.618
IP protocol itself, which normally
is on layer three of the OSI model.

124
00:07:06.618 --> 00:07:09.634
And if you're not familiar with that,
make sure you go back to check out

125
00:07:09.634 --> 00:07:12.415
the Cisco CCENT show that Zach and
I were also involved in as well.

126
00:07:12.415 --> 00:07:13.887
>> Important.

127
00:07:13.887 --> 00:07:16.380
>> Because that will help
you to understand something.

128
00:07:16.380 --> 00:07:22.600
IP itself, even though it's been there for
a long time, it has no built-in security.

129
00:07:22.600 --> 00:07:25.850
So there's no inherent
security about IP itself.

130
00:07:25.850 --> 00:07:30.270
It's about addressing,
it's about functionality, but no security.

131
00:07:30.270 --> 00:07:36.200
So everything that we do to secure network
traffic based on layer three that you and

132
00:07:36.200 --> 00:07:41.680
I know about today, is really in
addition to the protocol itself.

133
00:07:41.680 --> 00:07:44.350
So that means there's a layered
approach where we've added in more.

134
00:07:44.350 --> 00:07:49.760
And that's where the IPSec comes from,
that security side of it, comes from.

135
00:07:49.760 --> 00:07:52.819
The very fact is that by itself,
when we just do IP,

136
00:07:52.819 --> 00:07:55.247
it's not there, so we have to do IPSec.

137
00:07:55.247 --> 00:08:01.078
Now when we talk about IPSec as well,
it is also what we call a framework, okay.

138
00:08:01.078 --> 00:08:04.635
So it's not just one protocol unto itself.

139
00:08:04.635 --> 00:08:09.595
Plus the framework of different elements
that are combined together to help

140
00:08:09.595 --> 00:08:14.260
us out to bring what we need to,
to have a secure connection in between.

141
00:08:15.270 --> 00:08:18.300
So when something like that happens, we're
gonna actually see that the different

142
00:08:18.300 --> 00:08:23.060
protocols include things like hashing
algorithms that are also out there,

143
00:08:23.060 --> 00:08:25.980
the ability to do authentication, okay.

144
00:08:25.980 --> 00:08:29.630
The ability, of course, to actually
create what we call a group for

145
00:08:29.630 --> 00:08:34.410
the key exchange that we actually want,
unlimited lifetime ability,

146
00:08:34.410 --> 00:08:37.620
as well as the ability to encrypt
the data and the traffic.

147
00:08:37.620 --> 00:08:38.360
And we can pick and

148
00:08:38.360 --> 00:08:42.440
choose from different protocols
that combine everything together.

149
00:08:42.440 --> 00:08:46.670
So, we're going to focus in on
the way that this ends up working for

150
00:08:46.670 --> 00:08:50.950
us, and working out, as well because
it really does help us understand.

151
00:08:50.950 --> 00:08:53.700
But key, is that when you remember and

152
00:08:53.700 --> 00:08:59.500
when we start talking about the idea
of IPsec itself, it's not one protocol.

153
00:08:59.500 --> 00:09:03.730
It is a framework that provides for us and
I'll have a nice little acronym for

154
00:09:03.730 --> 00:09:06.300
you to try and remember this by.

155
00:09:06.300 --> 00:09:09.100
Hashing, is kind of the key one.

156
00:09:09.100 --> 00:09:13.670
Authentication, we'll call a DH number or
a Diffie-Hellman group number.

157
00:09:13.670 --> 00:09:17.680
And then some limited lifetime and
then of course encryption.

158
00:09:17.680 --> 00:09:19.110

episodes.title: Describe Native VLAN Security Issues

episodes.title: Describe Different Firewall Technologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss the setting up Policy Based NAT on a Cisco ASA running version 9+.  They show of the configuration detail throught the ASDM.  Lastly, they demonstrate how to configure Policy NAT on the Cisco ASA.
episodes.title: Implement NAT on Cisco ASA 9.x

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie continue setting up Policy Based NAT on a Cisco ASA running version 9+.  Lastly, they verify the Policy NAT on the Cisco ASA.
